Holland to load gold from Amsterdam had sailed and should reachthis country that evening. The third ship was now being loaded.The position in regard to the gold at Rotterdam was uncertain. Itwas feared that a pilot steamer, on which it had been attempted to send gold down the river from Rotterdam to the Black Swan,had been sunk by a magnetic mine.Dutch shipping. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs said that hewas consulting The King as to whether we should offer the ex-Kaiserrefuge in this country. Subject to The King's approval, he was proposing to inform our Minister at The Hague that he might indicate that we should be prepared to offer the ex-Kaiser refugein this country.3. The Chief of the Imperial General Staff said that lord Gort was asking that the Armoured Division should be despatched to France. Without this Division, Lord Gort had noforce suitable for a counter-attack. If the Armoured Divisionwent to France, we should still have 160 light tanks in this country.Further, it was proposed to organise 12 troops of tanks of variousdescriptions, which, although not suitable for operations in France,would be very useful to deal with the contingency of invasion ofthis country. The Third Corps, which included the canadian division, were now fit for operations. Two motorised battalions and one motor-cycle battalion would also be kept in this country.It was agreed To authorise the move of the Armoured Division to France.Invasion of 4. The Prime Minister raised the question whether the PoliceGreat Britain. should be armed.Arming of General Ismay was instructed to take up this point with thePolice. Hampshire to Nairn) should be interned. No doubt 90 per cent, ofsuch aliens were well disposed to this country, but it was impossibleto pick out the small proportion of aliens who probably constituted a dangerous element. In the circumstances, the only course seemedto be that all aliens in this area should be interned for the present.The number was probably 4,000 or 5,000. The Home Secretary, who had been consulted, said that if thecourse was pressed on military grounds he would agree to it.It was agreed That the Home Secretary should be authorised to issue instructions for the internment of all male enemy aliensaged 16 to 60 in the area mentioned above, and for theimposition of severe restrictions on non-enemy aliens of thesame age. The First Sea Lord said that a telegram had been receivedfrom our Consul at Aruba saying that the Dutch authorities hadthe situation well in hand, and that the despatch of British troopsmight not be well received. The despatch of troops had, therefore,been countermanded.The Secretary of State for Foreign A ffairs said that on theprevious day he had agreed with the Dutch Minister that we should send troops, and the text of various documents as to the despatchof these troops had been settled. It seemed that there had been some misunderstanding between the Foreign Office and theAdmiralty over this matter, and the Foreign Secretary proposedthat this matter should be taken up between these two Departments.This was agreed to.Air Action. 6. The Prime Minister referred to the probable effect on publicopinion in Sweden of the invasion of Holland and Belgium. was it not worth while to try to make Sweden realise that germany had no regard for the interests of small nations ? If Swedencould be induced to come into the war on our side, the whole positionin Scandinavia would be changed.The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs undertook to put this point forcibly to the Swedish Minister, but without much hopethat it would affect Sweden's attitude.Next Meeting.8. It was agreed to meet again at 10 p.m. that night.Richmond Terrace, S.W. 1,May 11, 1940.
